Award.AwardTitle: A Community of Problem Solvers: Teachers Leading Problem-Based Learning in Southern Illinois

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Southern Illinois University Carbondale (SIUC), in partnership with Shawnee Community College (SCC), Boys and Girls Club of Carbondale, and over 12 high-need school districts in the region, is mentoring and preparing 20 Master Teaching Fellows (MTFs) to transform science and math teaching in the partner schools. Through courses, leadership activities, research experiences and involvement with training pre- and in-service science teachers, MTFs are establishing a sustainable community of problem-solvers. MTFs are mentored by SIUC and SCC STEM faculty and educators in a synergistic endeavor to strengthen inquiry-based science experiences for teachers and students. As the principal agents for educational reform, MTFs are acquiring a deep grounding in science and mathematics content, inquiry-based learning methods, instructional interventions, and Action Research skills. They are developing leadership skills in designing and implementing professional development activities for their fellow in-service teachers in the region and for pre-service teachers. SCC is a key link in this partnership as most students at SCC attended the partner school districts and transferred to SIUC to complete their undergraduate degrees. Collaborating with researchers and IGERT fellows, MTFs conduct scientific research at the Cache River Natural Area and develop Problem-Based Learning (PBL) exercises and materials for a Resource Center housed at SCC. A virtual community is also being established using a course management system to disseminate resources and promote team communication. This community-based approach leads to inquiry-based instruction, especially problem-based learning, in the middle grades and improved student performance in science and mathematics at this critical juncture in education. MTFs conduct mentored authentic research, which they then translate to PBL exercises for their classrooms and the Boys and Girls Club of Carbondale, and disseminate to other teachers. IGERT Fellows mentor the MTFs and guide them in implementation of classroom activities. Additional pre- and in-service teachers are engaging in similar projects with their students or through a summer research experience. The focus on a widely studied and attractive natural area is designed to draw teachers, students and their families into "backyard" or community science projects. Additional professional development components of the program for MTFs include enriching science, leadership and science pedagogy courses, workshops and lectures in existing courses that MTFs will assist SCC and SIUC faculty in teaching, induction of novice teachers, development of a PBL Resource Center, shared maintenance of the web site, and National Board Certification to transform teacher leadership in their schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary and Scientific Merit

The Robert Noyce Master Teaching Fellowship program entitled A Community of Problem-Solvers: Teachers Leading Problem-based Learning in Southern Illinois provided five years of environmental science, pedagogy and leadership training for 20 outstanding Master Teaching Fellows (MTFs) from rural schools in Southern Illinois. Program activities were centered at the Cache River Wetland, an ecological area of international importance, and focused on scientific training and authentic research. STEM and STEM education faculty and students from Southern Illinois University (SIU) and Shawnee Community College (SCC) mentored teachers and led the training throughout the duration of their experiences. Two overlapping cohorts of 10 MTFs engaged in a five-year program that prepared them as STEM education leaders. During the first year, they learned about and engaged in scientific research by completing an interactive seminar course on the Cache River Wetland ecosystem and another on scientific research methods. During the first summer, MTFs engaged in a Summer Research Experience for Teachers (SRET) during which they designed and conducted mentored and self-directed research at the Cache River. During the second year, MTFs completed graduate courses supporting the development of problem-based learning activities and accompanying action research. By the second summer, each MTF had integrated problem-based learning activities and research skills into their classroom curricula. Each subsequent year in the program, MTFs enrolled in science content, pedagogy and leadership courses during the academic year and engaged in research intensive SRETs each summer. They conducted outreach and dissemination activities and served as leaders in their schools and districts. Teacher participants learned to integrate and embed mathematics in their course work through SRET activities.

The MTF Experience

By the end of the program, MTFs 1) developed leadership skills and became leaders in their schools and community, 2) designed, implemented and participated in five SRETs, 3) disseminated results of their activities to wider professional audiences, 4) completed graduate courses, 5) developed problem-based and place-based activities for their classrooms, 6) conducted mentored authentic research and translated the skills into classroom activities, 7) trained and led pre-and in-service participants in exploratory science activities, 8) partnered with the Carbondale Science Center to enhance displays and learning activities for local youth, and 9) developed resources for educators in the region and beyond.

Educational Community 

Our community of problem-solvers program engaged over 45 in-service and five pre-service teachers in research-based activities. Hundreds of additional pre-service teachers were trained by MTFs in courses at SIU and as visitors in MTF classrooms. Outcomes included new teacher partnerships across Southern Illinois where teachers shared (and continue to do so) expertise, resources, and support for improved and innovative classroom and community activities such as STEAM Nights, native and pollinator garden development, and eclipse activities. A subaward from the Noyce Midwest Regional Conference supported a collaboration between the SIUE Noyce Scholarship and SIUC MTF Programs. Pre-service teachers from SIUE worked side-by-side with MTFs from SIUC in their classrooms to integrate hands-on activities using tardigrades and assess the impact on student learning. The results of their efforts were presented at the Illinois State Academy of Science and at other professional conferences.

Dissemination

Through the course of the program, teachers developed writing and communication skills and presented results of the project in a range of professional venues. They described their findings related to scientific research, novel approaches to pedagogy, program activities, and innovations in the classroom. Program faculty and staff also contributed to dissemination of results. We had 66 professional presentations over the course of the program that included regional, state, national and international science and science education conferences. Two MTFs published authentic research in scientific journals and one presented a poster at the 14th International Tardigrade Symposium in Copenhagen, Denmark.

Broader Impact and Sustainability

The program had a significant impact on education in Southern Illinois by bringing resources, innovation, and expertise together and making them available to hundreds of teachers. The program brought teaching materials, equipment, and resources into classrooms. We trained the teachers to write grants to seek additional funding for instrumentation and educational supplies. Our teachers continue to transform STEM education through their efforts to partner and lead the schools and school districts across our region. Through our network of teachers, we reach thousands of students and groom them to be literate in science and interested in STEM professions. Our emphasis on scientific inquiry and problem-based learning has made science content more relevant and engaging. Our teacher leaders continue to infuse these approaches into our classrooms, thereby ensuring that our efforts are sustained and strengthened.  

            In addition to the program website, our teachers developed the following four websites/ blogs to unite the teaching community and ensure the sustainability of elements of the programs.

  • Backyard Science and Other Mysteries of the Earth
    https://scienceinthebackyard.blogspot.com/  
  • SITardigrada.org
    https://www.sitardigra.org  
  • Southern Illinois Schools' Native Gardens Network
    https://sischoolsnativegardens.wordpress.com/join-us/  
  • Southern Illinois Teachers Eclipse Planning Group
    https://sischoolseclipseplanning.wordpress.com/
